"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Summarized chunk:
Congress findings include the attacks on Pearl Harbor and the Philippines by Imperial Japanese forces, the defense efforts of United States and Philippine Forces, and the actions of the 200th Coast Artillery Regiment in December 1941. (4) Troops from the United States and the Philippines bravely defended Bataan for over 4 months, facing starvation and disease.
(5) Their actions delayed the Japanese timetable, allowing Allied forces to regroup and prepare for the liberation of the Pacific.
(6) Major General Edward King surrendered on April 9, 1942, due to starvation and lack of supplies. The soldiers from the United States and the Philippines surrendered due to starvation and lack of supplies. They were taken prisoner and forced to march 65 miles without food, water, or medical care in the "Bataan Death March", where thousands died from various causes. Prisoner of war camps had appalling conditions, leading to increased disease and malnutrition among the prisoners. At Camp O'Donnell, nearly 400 prisoners died per day due to poor conditions. Between September 1942 and December 1944, American prisoners of war who survived the Bataan Death March were transferred to Camp Cabanatuan and then shipped north on "hell ships" for forced labor. Many died due to abysmal conditions, with nearly 1,800 American lives lost in the sinking of the Arisan Maru. The prisoners who survived the Bataan Death March endured mistreatment, malnutrition, and horrific conditions until their liberation in 1945. The veterans of Bataan, representing the best of America and the Philippines, formed support groups and were honored in memorials. The United States Navy named ships after the battle to honor their valor. Many survivors have since passed away. Many survivors of the Bataan Death March have passed away, but those who remain are honored for their courage and perseverance during World War II. They endured capture, imprisonment, and atrocious conditions with dignity, honor, patriotism, and loyalty. Many survivors of the Bataan Death March are honored for their courage and perseverance during World War II. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a gold medal to be awarded to honor the troops from the US and the Philippines who defended Bataan and were prisoners of war in World War II. The design of the medal will be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. After the award, the gold medal will be given to the Smithsonian Institution. The gold medal awarded to honor troops from the US and the Philippines who defended Bataan in World War II will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display and research. Congress suggests displaying the medal at locations associated with Bataan prisoners of war. SEC. 3. DUPLICATE MEDALS.

The Secretary may strike bronze duplicates of the gold medal and sell them to cover costs.

SEC. 4. NATIONAL MEDALS.

Medals struck under this Act are considered National medals.

SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. Authorization of Appropriations; Proceeds of Sale: Up to $30,000 from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund is authorized for the medal cost under section 2. Sales of duplicate bronze medals under section 3 will be deposited into the Fund.
